intro: Brassica napus var. leptorhiza, commonly known as the wild radish, is a biennial or annual plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, cruciform flowers and seed pods. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, with hairy stems and alternate, lance-shaped leaves. Its roots are taprooted and often have a strong, pungent odor. It is an important species in ecological studies due to its role in soil stabilization and as a host plant for various insect species.
